abstract.p: Mark Stuart Ellison letter points to greed as one reason for decline in pro bono work by lawyers (S)

block.p: I am outraged, but not surprised, that the country's biggest law firms are cutting back on pro bono work (front page, Aug. 17). As your article noted, paying for the increased starting salaries among associates is the supposed driving force behind this trend. That is only partly true.

I am outraged, but not surprised, that the country's biggest law firms are cutting back on pro bono work (front page, Aug. 17). As your article noted, paying for the increased starting salaries among associates is the supposed driving force behind this trend. That is only partly true.

There is a more basic factor at work here: greed. Associates have been under pressure to produce more billable hours for years. When I graduated from law school in 1994, the industry was in recession, and many firms were going under. But today business is booming. It is absurd for a law firm raking in millions of dollars, and employing hundreds of lawyers at six-figure salaries, to say it cannot afford to have its lawyers comply with rules of professional ethics and donate 50 hours a year to help society's least fortunate members.
